tossups.question: After fighting the KKK, this state's William Woods Holden was the first governor to be removed through impeachment. The non-Italian Red Shirts began to disappear from this state after helping Charles B. Aycock, "the Education governor," defeat Spencer B. Adams. In the only successful coup in US history, one Fusionist government in this state was overthrown by a white mob. That 1898 event occured in this state's city of (*) Wilmington. Bennett Place, the site of the last major surrender of the civil war, is located outside this state's city of Durham. A lost colony in this state was the site of the civil war Battle of Roanoke Island. For 10 points, name this state where Roy Cooper governs from Raleigh.

An essay by this man compares "pounding on this door" with a "total desperation to enter," only for it to reveal that "we've been inside what we wanted all along" to finding the humor in Kafka. One essay by this writer recounts his trip to the 1998 Adult Video News awards, while in another he describes a weeklong trip on the cruise ship Zenith. This author, who gave a commencement speech at Kenyon College titled (*) "This is Water," discussed whether boiling animals for "gustatory pleasure" is moral in his essay "Consider the Lobster." A novel by this man set in the "Year of the Depend Adult Undergarment" is titled for a film that is so entertaining that its viewers die. For 10 points, name this writer who created Hal Incandenza in Infinite Jest.

One of these compounds undergoes a 4 plus 2 cycloaddition with an azide in a reaction considered the "cream of the crop" of click chemistry. That reaction is named after Huisgen. These compounds are formed when alkyl dihalides undergo two E2 reactions using a strong base. The "terminal" types of these compounds are highly acidic. Palladium is deposited on calcium carbonate in (*) Lindlar's catalyst, which is used for the partial hydrogenation of these compounds. These compounds' characteristic functional group contains one sigma bond and two pi bonds. The simplest one of these compounds is acetylene. For 10 points, name these compounds characterized by a carbon-carbon triple bond.
tossups.answer: alkynes [accept internal or terminal alkynes; prompt on hydrocarbons; do not accept or prompt on "alkanes" or "alkenes"]
tossups.answer_formatted: alkynes [accept internal or terminal alkynes; prompt on hydrocarbons; do not accept or prompt on "alkanes" or "alkenes"]

tossups.question: One painting by this artist is thought to represent Hercules rescuing Alcestis from the underworld and depicts a red figure holding a limp woman; that work is The Abduction. Many members of Les Nabis are present in a "Homage" to this artist by Maurice Denis. This artist depicted a man ripping the covers off of a reclining nude woman in his response to Edouard (*) Manet's work Olympia. This person used triangular shaped patterns with the trees and title nude figures in another of this artist's paintings; that work is The Large Bathers. This artist often portrayed fruits in his still-lifes. This artist would become well-known for his portraits of a certain landmark while staying in Provence. For 10 points, name this artist who often depicted Mont-Sainte Victoire.

In one text in this religion, a man wonders if his 'buttocks turn into cartwheels" after death, and says that he will "ascend into the sky with his spirit as a horse." A man rebuffs another's argument by mentioning how walking makes him happy in a debate in this religion about the happiness of fish. This religion urges people to be like uncarved wood, or pu, when describing ziran. This religion's founder is shown having a (*) sweet expression in the allegory of the vinegar tasters. One scholar in this religion asked if he was a man dreaming he was a butterfly or a butterfly dreaming he was a man in the Zhuangzi. A concept central to this religion is "action through inaction," or "wu wei." For 10 points, name this Chinese religion founded by Lao Tzu.

Charles de Monchy was saved by this ruler's general at the Battle of Bléneau. This non-American ruler used ravelins as part of their third system of fortification. This person had an affair with the Duchess of La Vallière, which he hid from his mother, Anne of Austria. In a rebellion nicknamed after the slingshots used to smash windows, this ruler's former general, the Prince of Condé, was defeated by (*) Turenne. That rebellion is known as the Fronde. This ruler fought the Grand Alliance in the Nine Years' War. This king's chief minister was Cardinal Mazarin. This king signed the Edict of Fontainebleau, which revoked the 1598 Edict of Nantes. For 10 points, name this longest reigning French king who was known as the "Sun King."
tossups.answer: Louis XIV [accept Louis the Great or Louis le Grand; prompt on Louis; prompt on Sun King] [the second line refers to Vauban]
tossups.answer_formatted: Louis XIV [the second line refers to Vauban] [the second line refers to Vauban] [accept Louis the Great or Louis le Grand; prompt on Louis; prompt on Sun King]
acceptable: Louis XIV [the second line refers to Vauban]
Louis XIV [the second line refers to Vauban]

tossups.question: A tribunal that is held in this location, composed of nine ancestral spirits, orders a character to take wine to his in-laws and beg his wife to come back home with him. One character who lives in this location cries after learning how newborn twins are taken to the Forest of Evil from this place. That character from this location changes his name to Isaac after being converted to (*) Christianity by Mr. Brown. A character who lives in this location resents his lazy flute playing father Unoka and gained prominence after winning a wrestling match against Amalinze the Cat. The protagonist of a novel set in this location is exiled after his gun exploded and killed Ezeudu's son during a funeral. For 10 points, name this village which serves as the home of Okonkwo in Chinua Achebe's Things Fall Apart.
tossups.answer: Umuofia [prompt on Africa or Nigeria or Igboland by asking "can you be more specific?"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Umuofia [prompt on Africa or Nigeria or Igboland by asking "can you be more specific?]

tossups.question: The Dupuit-Thiem equation assesses these structures under steady-state conditions. A slug test is performed to determine the characteristics of these structures. The equation Q = KA over dh/dl was developed to apply to these structures. The perched variety of these structures lies above another in the vadose zone. Over-access of these structures, which are measured by (*) Darcy's Law, can lead to saline intrusions. Percolation recharges these structures, which form artesian systems in areas under pressure. The largest one of these structures in the U.S. is the Ogallala one in the Great Plains. The water table lies at the top of these structures. For 10 points, name these underground layers of rock which store groundwater.
tossups.answer: aquifers [prompt on groundwater or water table]

tossups.question: This mountain range is the subject of Joaquin Miller's most famous poetry collection. The Maidu people inhabit this mountain range. In the foothills of this mountain range, floods threatened to overwhelm the Oroville Dam. This mountain range contains large basaltic columns at Devils Postpile. The Kaweah and Kern rivers drain much of the southern portion of this mountain range, while the American, (*) Stanislaus, and Tuolumne all drain the northern portion. Tulare County in this mountain range is home to General Sherman, the world's largest living tree. This mountain range's Mount Whitney lies in Sequoia National Park, while this mountain range also contains much of Yosemite National Park. For 10 points, name this mountain range which covers much of eastern California.
tossups.answer: Sierra Nevada [prompt on North American Cordillera]

tossups.question: In one work, this artist asked the listener to "take me to the lakes where all the poets went to die." One album cover by this artist depicts a polaroid picture with the artist's initials and year of birth written underneath. One song by this artist begins "Salt air, and the rust on your door" before continuing that the namesake month "slipped away into a moment in time." Another song by this artist has the lines "Headlights pass the window pane / I think of you." This artist wrote the songs (*) "I Wish You Would" and "Out of the Woods." This artist worked with Jack Antonoff to produce the albums 1989 and Folklore. One song by this artist begins with "Nice to meet you, where you been? / I could show you incredible things" before continuing "I'll write your name" next to the title concept. For 10 points, name this artist who sang "Blank Space" and "Bad Blood."

This country executed Jopie Fourie for his role in the Maritz Rebellion. In that rebellion, a roadblock set up to catch the Foster Gang led to the death of Koos de la Rey. The Fagan Commission was supported by much of this country's United Party, which included much of this country's National Party led by J.B.M. Hertzog. A leader of this country was the only signer of the Treaty of Versailles to sign the UN Charter. The (*) Defiance Campaign in this country protested against its system of pass laws. The Colony of Natal merged with three others to form this country, where the Sharpeville Massacre took place. Jan Smuts was a prime minister of this country, which was also led by F.W. de Klerk. For 10 points, name this country formed after the Second Boer War where apartheid developed.

Mark Strand says that "I am not thinking of [this thing], but [this thing] is thinking of me" in his poem "2002." In a poem partially titled for this phenomenon, the speaker describes a boy who is invited to be "the smallest page at court," as well as pictures of "King George with Queen Mary" and a "stuffed loon" shot by Arthur's father. In addition to that poem about this phenomenon in "Nova Scotia", another poem titled for this phenomenon describes how "the Dews grew quivering" after the speaker (*) passed the "Fields of Gazing Grain." That poem describes how the speaker "put away / My labor and my leisure too / For [this figure]'s Civility." A poet described how this figure "knew no haste" while driving a carriage that "held but just Ourselves  --  And Immortality." For 10 points, name this figure that the speaker "could not stop for" in an Emily Dickinson poem.
tossups.answer: death [accept "First Death in Nova Scotia"; accept "Because I could not stop for Death"]
tossups.answer_formatted: death [accept First Death in Nova Scotia; accept Because I could not stop for Death]
acceptable: Because I could not stop for Death

tossups.question: An imbalance between elastase and a compound beginning with this letter can cause emphysema, a type of lung disease. Lewy body dementia is caused by the buildup of one compound beginning with this letter; that compound is also used as a marker for Parkinson's. A structure named after this letter appears in the upper right of a Ramachandran plot. Tumors in cells denoted by this letter cause excess secretion of (*) glucagon and are suppressed by insulin. Starch contains glycolytic bonds named after this letter. A structure denoted by this letter turns every 3.6 amino acid residues and is stabilized by hydrogen bonds. For 10 points, name this letter that denotes a type of helix found in protein secondary structure contrasted with beta sheets.
tossups.answer: alpha [accept alpha-1-antitrypsin or alpha-synuclein or alpha helix or alpha cells; prompt on AAT]
tossups.answer_formatted: alpha [accept alpha-1-antitrypsin or alpha-synuclein or alpha helix or alpha cells; prompt on AAT]

tossups.question: Jun Nagao arranged an addition to this piece for the Trouvère Quartet in 2003, which includes a part for saxophone. At the beginning of the fifth movement of this piece, flutes, bassoons and harps play a theme suggestive of a ticking clock. Colin Matthews was commissioned by the Hallé Orchestra to add an addition to this piece partially named after "the Renewer." The first movement of this piece begins with (*) col legno strings playing in 5/4 time. This piece's final movement ends with a "fade out" effect produced by a door being slowly shut on an offstage women's chorus. One movement of this piece was adapted into the hymn "I Vow to Thee, My Country", while another served as inspiration for John Williams' Star Wars soundtrack. For 10 points, name this suite by Gustav Holst that includes sections like Neptune, Jupiter, and Mars.

Broteas, a person with this profession, was forced to self immolate after he refused to sculpt another goddess on a mountain after sculpting Cybele. One person with this profession, who was the center of a hero cult in Boeotia, may have been born after three gods urinated into a bull's hide. One man with this profession was blinded by Oenopion after attacking (*) Merope. A person with this profession was transformed into a stag and torn apart by dogs after witnessing a goddess bathing. One hero was killed by a scorpion for boasting about his prowess in this profession. Another person with this profession collaborated with Meleager to kill the Calydonian Boar. For 10 points, name this profession of people like Atalanta and Orion, whose patron goddess was Artemis.

This ruler ordered the construction of an obelisk left unfinished in an Aswan quarry, which would have been the largest in the country then. This ruler's daughter Neferure may have been married to this ruler's successor. This ruler, who was sometimes called Maatkare, added twin obelisks to Karnak as well as the Red Chapel. This ruler's architect Senenmut built the Djeser-Djeseru as a mortuary temple in (*) Deir el-Bahari. This ruler sent Nehsi on a large expedition to Puntland that transplanted trees. This wife of Thutmose II may have had her monuments defaced by Thutmose III, her co-regent. For 10 points, name this longest-reigning female pharaoh of Ancient Egypt.

A character in this play asks "Who does the clearing up?" before wondering if "Maybe they just leave them there." A newspaper in this play reports the story of an 8 year old girl who killed her cat as well as an old man who is run over after crawling under a truck. Two characters in this play discuss a football match between the Villa and Tottenham and later argue over the phrase (*) "Light the Kettle." A house in this play is theorized by those characters to belong to an unnamed man named Wilson, and they receive notes like "Two braised steak and chips" and "Two sago puddings" from the title device. This play ends with one character pulling a gun on someone who comes through the door, only to realize the person is his partner. For 10 points, name this play about the hitmen Gus and Ben, a work by Harold Pinter.

This person names an equation that describes the time evolution of a non-equilibrium particle distribution function. This person is the namesake of a quantity equal to e to the power of negative beta times energy, and the classical partition function equals the sum of those namesake "factors." This person's H theorem can be derived from their namesake (*) transport equation. This man showed that entropy was proportional to the logarithm of the number of microstates, which is engraved on his tombstone. For a monatomic ideal gas, average kinetic energy equals three-halves times temperature times this man's namesake constant. For 10 points, name this scientist whose namesake constant is symbolized k-sub-b.
tossups.answer: Ludwig Boltzmann [accept Boltzmann transport equation or Boltzmann factor or Boltzmann H theorem or Boltzmann constant]
tossups.answer_formatted: Ludwig Boltzmann [accept Boltzmann transport equation or Boltzmann factor or Boltzmann H theorem or Boltzmann constant]

tossups.question: In one work, this person portrays characters named "Donkey Teeth" and "Ozamataz Buckshank." In another work, this person plays a referee who flags Hingle McCringleberry for excessive celebration. In a movie directed by this person, a character mistakenly plays an N.W.A. song when trying to call the police. In that movie, the Beach Boys song Good Vibrations is played during the murder of (*) Kitty and Josh. The Wilson family drives to Santa Cruz on a vacation before meeting the Tethered in one movie by this man. Chris Washington escapes from the Armitage House in a movie by this man. For 10 points, name this director of Us and Get Out who made many comedy sketches with Keegan Michael-Key.

One figure in this work argues that it is "not in the nature of things that a bad man should injure a better than himself." In this work, a man refutes an argument by likening himself to a "trainer of horses." That man in this work compares believing in divine agency but not gods to believing "in flute-playing, and not in flute-players." This work concludes with a man claiming that (*) death is either a "state of nothingness" or a "journey to another place," and that dying is nothing to fear. The speaker of this work describes how the Oracle at Delphi said there was no wiser man than him. The central figure of this work calls himself a "gadfly." Meletus and Anytus charge this work's speaker with atheism and corruption of the youth. For 10 points, name this Platonic dialogue depticing the trial of Socrates.
tossups.answer: The Apology of Socrates [or Apologia Socratis]

bonuses.leadin: The foramen ovale is a hole present in this organ before a baby is born. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this organ divided into atria and ventricles. This organ's namesake beat is regulated by pacemakers.
This technique measures the electrical activity of the heart. The namesake machines of this technique commonly use 12 leads.
The depolarization of the ventricles produces this part of an electrocardiogram. This is the most prominent part of an ECG and is named after the three waves it contains.
answers: electrocardiography [accept electrocardiogram or ECG machine or EKG machine; do not accept or prompt on "echocardiography" or "echocardiogram" or "EEG"]
answers_formatted: electrocardiography [accept electrocardiogram or ECG machine or EKG machine; do not accept or prompt on "echocardiography" or "echocardiogram" or "EEG"]

bonuses.leadin: One movement in this work is called "Of Science." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this tone poem whose introduction, "Sunrise," opens with a "Low C, G, High C" played by the trumpets. The last section of this work is called the "Song of the Night Wanderer."
Also sprach Zarathustra is by this German composer. This composer's operas include Elektra and Der Rosenkavalier.
Richard Strauss also composed this tone poem whose first of 22 movements is called Night. This was the first work to be pressed into a compact disk.
answers: Also sprach Zarathustra, Op. 30 [or Thus Spake Zarathustra or Thus Spoke Zarathustra]
Richard Strauss [or Richard Georg Strauss; prompt on Strauss]
An Alpine Symphony, Op. 64 [or Eine Alpensinfonie]
answers_formatted: Also sprach Zarathustra, Op. 30 [or Thus Spake Zarathustra or Thus Spoke Zarathustra]

bonuses.leadin: Sir Halliday Macartney held this man hostage in a London embassy, which he described in the memoir Kidnapped in London. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who led the Xinhai revolution that toppled the Qing dynasty. This man served as the provisional first president of the Republic of China.
After Sun Yat-Sen's death, Chiang Kai Shek defeated this government, unifying China in the Northern Expedition. The Warlord Era began after the death of this government's leader, Yuan Shikai.
After the Northern Expedition, Chiang Kai-Shek was defeated in the Chinese Civil War and retreated to this island. Chiang relocated the Republic of China to this island, whose capital is at Taipei.
answers: Beiyang government [or Peiyang government; accept chunghua minkuo; prompt on First Republic of China]
answers_formatted: Beiyang government [or Peiyang government; accept chunghua minkuo; prompt on First Republic of China]

bonuses.leadin: Joseph Weydemeyer coined this term, which Karl Marx used to describe the Paris Commune. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this situation in which the post-revolutionary state seizes the means of production and serves as a transition stage between a capitalist and communist economy. This situation was discussed in the Critique of the Gotha Program.

Marx defined a dictatorship as an entire one of these groups holding political and economical control. In the Communist Manifesto, Marx called the history of all society the struggle between these groups such as the bourgeois and the "working" one.

In the Critique of the Gotha Program, Marx criticised the theoretical influence of this person on the German labour movement. This person founded the ADAV, the first organized mass working-class party in European history.
answers: class [accept class struggle; accept working class]

bonuses.leadin: Walter Hussman was accused of pressuring a committee not to give tenure to this person, who was given a Knight Chair. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this former UNC professor of journalism who was controversially not approved for tenure in 2021.

Hannah-Jones earlier edited a collection of essays named for this year about the impacts of slavery and discrimination on the United States. The project considers this the year when the first slaves were brought to the current U.S.A.
The 1619 project was published by this newspaper. This newspaper's slogan is "All The News that's Fit to Print" and is nicknamed the "gray lady."

bonuses.leadin: In a play written by this man, three guards resume playing cards after the title character, Haemon, and Eurydice have all died. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French dramatist who adapted Antigone as a parable of the Vichy regime.
The original Antigone was written by this Greek tragedian. Oedipus Rex and Oedipus at Colonus are the other installments of his Theban plays.

Anouilh also adapted this other classical Greek play. In the traditional version of this play, the title character murders Creon's daughter Glauce with a poisoned robe before murdering her own children and escaping to Athens.

bonuses.leadin: The eventual victors of this conflict were crushed at the Disaster of Annual, where they lost over 10,000 soldiers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1920s conflict where colonial forces defeated Berber tribes of a namesake mountainous region in Morocco, who were led by Abd el-Krim.
This man was promoted to Brigadier-General after leading the Spanish Foreign Legion to victory in the Rif War. This man' Nationalist forces defeated the Republicans in the Spanish Civil War.

Following the Years of Hunger, Franco implemented the Stabilization plan to liberalize the Spanish economy after the failure of this type of national economy. A country is entirely self-sufficient and does not participate in trade in this type of national economy.

bonuses.leadin: Scholars of religion have put forth contrasting theories about how the Bible was actually written. For 10 points each:
parts: The two-source hypothesis states that this book and Mark were used to write Matthew and Luke. This hypothetical collection of various sayings of Jesus is generally denoted by an English letter.

This theory argues that the Torah was compiled by a redactor from sources denoted J, E, D, and P. This theory is contrasted with the traditional view that Moses transcribed the Old Testament from God.
Many Biblical scholars credit this man with writing Romans and 1-2 Corinthians, which are traditionally attributed to him, but this apostle from Tarsus likely did not write 1-2 Timothy.
answers: Q source [accept Q hypothesis or Quelle]

bonuses.leadin: One poem by this writer describes "the edge of all there is" as "so brutal and alive it seemed to comprehend us back." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poet who drew on Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey to write her poem, "My God, It's Full of Stars." She won the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for her collection Life on Mars.
Smith was the Poet Laureate of this country from 2017 to 2019. In January 2021, Amanda Gorman read her poem "The Hill We Climb" in this country's capital of Washington, DC.

Smith used the style of blackout poetry to create a poem based on this American document, opening her poem by claiming "he has / sent hither swarms of Officers to harass our people." This document contains a list of 27 grievances.
answers: United States of America [or United States of America or US or USA]
Declaration of Independence [the poem referenced is called "Declaration"]
answers_formatted: United States of America [or United States of America or US or USA]
Declaration of Independence [the poem referenced is called "Declaration"]

bonuses.leadin: These materials' namesake property is typically displayed at low temperatures. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these materials that display the Meissner effect. The "high-temperature" variety of these materials operate above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen.
This quantity is defined as the distance in a superconductor where the magnetic field is 1 over e times as strong compared to the surface.
One structure named for this scientist forms between electrons in superconductors. This scientist proposed a namesake theory of superconductivity along with Bardeen and Schrieffer.
answers: superconductor [accept Type-I or Type-II superconductors; accept superconductivity; do not accept or prompt on "conductor"]
London penetration depth [accept lambda-L; prompt on lambda]
Leon Cooper [accept Cooper pair; prompt on BCS theory]
answers_formatted: superconductor [accept Type-I or Type-II superconductors; accept superconductivity; do not accept or prompt on "conductor"]

bonuses.leadin: The title story of a collection by this author ends by telling the reader to "Contemplate the marvel that is existence, and rejoice that you are able to do so." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author, who wrote about a race of androids coming to terms with the heat death of the universe in his 2019 collection, "Exhalation."

In Chiang's story "The Merchant and the Alchemist's Gate," a black stone arch is used to perform this action by various people in medieval Baghdad. The protagonist of an H.G. Wells novella performs this action to reach A.D. 802,701.

A classic of time travel fiction is this author's story "All You Zombies", where it is revealed that a man is both his own mother and father. This author also wrote novels such as Stranger in a Strange Land and The Moon is a Harsh Mistress.

bonuses.leadin: Anne Lacaton and Jean-Philippe Vassal were the most recent people to be awarded this prize. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this prize sometimes referred to as the "Nobel prize of architecture." Zaha Hadid was the first woman to be awarded this prize.

This architect was awarded the first ever Pritzker Prize, including for his private residence in New Canaan, Connecticut, which was inspired by the Farnsworth House. He also designed Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel.

Many of the Pritzker winners have worked in this loose architectural style. This style, in contrast to a post- version, is distinguished by use of glass, steel, and concrete in minimalist and functional designs.

bonuses.leadin: This newspaper was named for Alexander Odoevsky's line "from a spark a fire will flare up." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this newspaper. This mouthpiece of the Russian Social Democratic Labor party was founded by Georgi Plekhanov and Vladimir Lenin, although Lenin left before it stopped publishing in 1905.

This revolutionary worked for a time on the Iskra newspaper. Because he posed a threat to Stalin's power, this revolutionary was forced to leave the Soviet Union and was stabbed and killed in Mexico City.
Iskra often supported this wing of the Russian Social Democratic Labor party, which was led by Julius Martov. They were opposed by the Bolsheviks.

bonuses.leadin: The contour type of this operation is performed along curves in the complex plane. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this operation commonly defined as the area under a curve. This operation is usually considered the inverse of differentiation.

This rule approximates definite integrals using parabolas. In this approximation, the value of the function at the interval's midpoint is weighted four times as much as the value of the function at the interval's endpoints.

Simpson's rule is a special case of these formulas for numerical integration. These formulas use Lagrange interpolation polynomials on evenly spaced points over the interval that the function is being integrated over.
answers: integral [accept integration or word forms; prompt on antiderivative or word forms]
Newton-Cotes formulas [or Newton-Cotes rules or Newton-Cotes quadrature rules]
answers_formatted: integral [accept integration or word forms; prompt on antiderivative or word forms]

bonuses.leadin: This artistic movement tended to paint people with elongated anatomy, as exemplified by the work of Pontormo. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artistic movement founded by students of Andrea del Sarto. Jacopo Tintoretto painted in this style.

This artist was influenced by Mannerists such as Tintoretto in his elongated depictions of subjects. This artist painted The Burial of the Count of Orgaz as well as a View of Toledo depicting a dark sky around it.

This El Greco painting shows elongated figures likely inspired by his Mannerist training. This painting, which likely inspired Les Demoiselles D'Avignon, shows robes being distributed per Revelation 6.
answers: The Vision of Saint John [accept The Fifth Seal of the Apocalypse; accept Profane Love; accept Opening of the Fifth Seal]
answers_formatted: The Vision of Saint John [accept The Fifth Seal of the Apocalypse; accept Profane Love; accept Opening of the Fifth Seal]
acceptable: The Fifth Seal of the Apocalypse

bonuses.leadin: The Euro 2020 soccer tournament was spread between multiple cities this year. For 10 points each, answer some questions about which cities they are:
parts: This city's Hampden Park is located in the Mount Florida neighborhood. This city on the River Clyde also contains an art museum in its Kelvingrove Park.
The Parken Stadium in this city also hosted Euro 2020 matches. The Tivoli Gardens are located in this city which also contains the Amalienborg palace.
Another host location was the Arena Naţională in this city. This city is the capital of Romania.

bonuses.leadin: One type of these reactions uses chromium trioxide and is named after Jones. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these reactions where a reactant loses electrons. Another one of these reactions is named after Baeyer and Villiger.
This acid is commonly used to convert cyclic ketones to lactones in the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation. This chlorine-containing compound is the most common peroxyacid used to convert alkenes to epoxides.
Lactones are cyclic examples of this functional group. This functional group can also be formed by reacting an alcohol with a carboxylic acid in the presence of an acid catalyst.
answers: oxidation [accept Jones oxidation; accept Baeyer-Villiger oxidation; prompt on redox or reduction-oxidation reactions; do not accept or prompt on "reduction"]
answers_formatted: oxidation [accept Jones oxidation; accept Baeyer-Villiger oxidation; prompt on redox or reduction-oxidation reactions; do not accept or prompt on "reduction"]

bonuses.leadin: Upon entering this place, a person has the choice of returning to the six realms of existence as a bodhisattva or reaching full buddhahood to deliver beings to the shore of liberation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this place where, in some Buddhist sects, anyone can be reborn simply by engaging in nianfo, which means chanting the name of its principal Buddha.
Pure Land Buddhism is popular in this country, which is also home to the Soto, Rinzai, and Obaku branches of Zen Buddhism.
For Shinran and some other Pure Land Buddhists, the Pure Land was to some extent synonymous with this state. This state is generally considered the same as the ending of dukkha.
answers: the Pure Land [accept the Western Paradise or Sukhavati]

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, a private militia known as the Minute Men crack down on dissent while the narrator joins the Canada-based resistance group called the New Underground. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Sinclair Lewis novel in which Buzz Windrip wins the 1936 presidential election, establishing a totalitarian state in the United States.

This author's The Man in the High Castle imagines a world where the Axis powers defeat the Allies and sees the United States divided into regions controlled by Imperial Japan and Nazi Germany. In this author's novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?, Rick Deckard is tasked with retiring escaped androids.

This author chronicled the rise of the corporate conglomerate known as the Oligarchy, who were ultimately overthrown by the Brotherhood of Man in his novel The Iron Heel. This author also described conflict with nature in his novels White Fang and The Call of the Wild.

bonuses.leadin: In this politician's first race for the Senate, he defeated Coke Stevenson in a primary election that was marked by numerous challenges to the official results, many centering on Box 13. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this former senator from Texas. Robert Caro's multi-volume biography on the "Years" of this man describes how he became the Senate Majority Whip.
Johnson was supported in many of his early political endeavors by this House Speaker from Texas, who controlled the House most of the time from 1940 to 1961.
Johnson, as a congressional aide, and Rayburn both supported this series of programs against the Great Depression established by Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
